items.title: TikTok goes dark in the US ahead of ban
items.summary:
- TikTok stopped functioning in the US on January 19, 2025, ahead of a federal ban.
- The app was removed from Apple’s App Store and Google’s Play Store after Congress mandated ByteDance to sell it or face a ban.
- TikTok argued that divestment was not feasible for multiple reasons.
- Previous efforts to ban TikTok began in 2020 under Donald Trump.
- Users received messages stating that TikTok could not be used, with references to President Trump's potential assistance.
- The Supreme Court ruled the law banning TikTok as constitutional shortly before the deadline for the ban.
- TikTok's CEO has called for Trump's help to keep the app available in the US.
- Trump indicated he might provide a 90-day reprieve after taking office.

items.title: Trump says he will likely grant TikTok a 90-day reprieve from US ban when he takes office
items.summary:
- Donald Trump plans to give TikTok a 90-day reprieve from a potential US ban after taking office.
- He is considering this extension before a Sunday deadline for TikTok's parent company to sell to a non-Chinese buyer or face a ban.
- TikTok hopes for clarity and assurance from the US government amid its legal challenges and ongoing discussions with the new administration.

items.title: ‘A lot of chaos, quickly’: panic grips US music industry as ‘kingmaker’ TikTok faces ban
items.summary:
- TikTok, crucial for music promotion since 2017, faces potential ban amid national security concerns
- US Congress has mandated TikTok's parent company, ByteDance, to sell the app or face shutdown
- Supreme Court is set to decide on the ban, causing anxiety among artists and marketers
- TikTok's algorithmic feed significantly influences music trends and chart success globally
- Some industry professionals see potential creativity resurgence if TikTok is banned

items.title: Never have stale crisps again… nine invaluable things I’ve learned from TikTok
items.summary:
- Users spend an average of one hour daily on TikTok, but screen time for Americans may decrease due to a potential ban in the USA.
- The US Supreme Court upheld a law to ban TikTok over national security concerns.
- TikTok’s parent company, ByteDance, plans to challenge the law, which affects over 170 million users in the US.
- Many users are posting farewell videos as they switch to alternatives like Red Note.
- Positive TikTok trends include helpful 'life-changing tips' shared by users.
- Nine lessons learned from TikTok include:
  1. Roll limes and lemons before squeezing for more juice.
  2. Use cushion inserts larger than covers for plumper cushions.
  3. Place a damp towel under chopping boards to prevent sliding.
  4. Tie dressing gowns correctly to keep them secure.
  5. Fold crisps bags to keep them fresh without clips.
  6. Follow the mantra: “Don’t put it down, put it away.”
  7. Use a Lazy Susan for easy spice access.
  8. Grate cheese by turning the grater on its side.
  9. Use a hairdryer to remove sticky labels easily.

items.title: Chinese rival app Xiaohongshu is overwhelmed by ‘TikTok refugees’ in US
items.summary:
- Over 3 million US users signed up for Xiaohongshu in a week as TikTok faces a potential ban in the US due to national security concerns.
- Xiaohongshu, also known as RedNote, is a Chinese social media app focused on shopping and travel tips, with over 300 million users and valued at $17 billion.
- The app’s moderators are struggling to manage rising user numbers in accordance with Chinese censorship laws, leading to increased content moderation challenges.

items.title: When kids set their parents’ screen time rules: ‘I hit my limit before I even get out of bed’
items.author: Zoe Williams
items.summary:
- Discussion on the disparity in screen time regulation between children and parents.
- Parents often overlook their own screen time habits, impacting familial interaction and child development.
- The author experimented with her teenage son's screen time limits, revealing challenges and insights about technology use in family dynamics.

items.title: The tech bros have front-row seats at Trump’s inauguration, but what they want goes way beyond that
items.author: Quinn Slobodian
items.summary:
- In his farewell speech, Joe Biden described the US as an oligarchy, highlighting concerns about wealth concentration.
- At least 13 billionaires are set to hold government positions under Trump, with an expected cabinet worth $7 billion.
- Silicon Valley figures, including Elon Musk and David Sacks, are poised for significant influence in the Trump administration.
- The article points to a growing convergence of corporate and political power, especially concerning tech and investment sectors.
- There is speculation about the future political strategy of tech moguls, who may seek to reduce regulations and enjoy greater profit margins.

Winter running gear: our top training essentials to help you conquer the cold
items.author: Lisa Buckingham
items.summary:
- Winter running can be enjoyable and beneficial for mental health.
- Essential gear includes protective headgear, chest lights, and more.
- Key items recommended are balances between warmth, visibility, and breathability.
- Outdoor running accessories are important for safety in low-light conditions.
- Recommendations include various brands and price points for each item's utility.
- Items such as the Arc’teryx balaclava, Proviz chest light, and Shokz headphones are highlighted.
- Emphasis on layering and moisture-wicking materials for comfort during winter workouts.
